description.narrative:
Livestock is the second most important economic activity in Niger, contributing 15% to the national budget, 13% to national GDP and35% to agricultural GDP. Despite the great importance of this activity, it is today confronted with many constraints that limit itsperformance and contribute to the socio-economic development of its practitioners. These constraints include climate crises, including droughts, uncontrolled bush fires that devastate much of the meager pastures annually, and the collection of straw that has become a source of income for certain categories of populations in search of adaptive strategies frequent crises, early drying of ponds and ponds limiting the development of distant pastures, invasion of grazing areas by unpopulated herbaceous species, and grazing of pastoral lands by wealthy traders and / or by rich breeders, contributing to the depletion of grazing areas and to serious difficulties in the organization of transhumance movements. All these problems related to the availability, accessibility and quality of pastures have negative repercussions on herd productivity (high mortality of newborns and lactating mothers, low production of meat and milk, etc.) and vulnerability of poor households, sometimes compromising their self-reliance and restoring their livelihoods after crises.
It is in this context that Oxfam is currently involved in the transhumance triangle (Aderbissanat - Abalak - Bermo) through financial support from the DGD for (i) meeting the basic needs of pastoral households, (ii) their livelihoods and (iii) strengthening the early warning and vulnerability monitoring system. But the 2016 drought disrupted the efforts of Oxfam and other development partners in the area. With a view to preserving the achievements of the current project and supporting populations to better cope with the shock of the 2016 feed deficit, Oxfam financed with its own funds, a two-month rapid assistance (March-April) which consisted of free distribution of livestock feed to vulnerable livestock farmers and the strengthening of stock of livestock food banks (BAB)

participating-org.narrative:
AREN, an endogenous breeders' association, was born in a very particular socio-political and economic context in Niger. Indeed : at the institutional level, civil society was almost absent or at least at the larval stage. At the socio-economic level, the pressure on pastoral lands is stronger and increasing, the degradation of natural resources intense, land conflicts frequent with extensionof agricultural land on the pastoral area at the political level, the country had just emerged from a A long period of exception characterized by the existence of a very strong military regime, the omnipotence of a traditional chieftaincy which had all the rightsto land. The consequences of the long droughts of 84 and 85 still exist. A significant number of pastoralists have not yet reconstituted their livestock and have remained below the poverty line and are living a precarious life for the care of the sedentary livestock. The successive years of drought, a difficult national socio-political environment for authoritarian regimes (La Baule conference) led, in the late 1980s, to a certain recognition of freedom of association and expression in Niger. The breeders took advantage of this period to develop consultations that culminated on June 19, 1990 in the creation of the Association for the Revitalization ofLivestock in Niger (AREN) by 12 breeders mandated by their community. Thus was born the first pastoral association of Niger. On 14 February 1991 AREN was recognized by order of the Ministry of the Interior. AREN is basically an association of nomadic or semi-nomadic breeders, and it wants to be open to all ethnic groups, whether Peulh, Touareg, Arab, Toubou, Kanuri, Hausa or other. The criterion that brings them together is the fact of being engaged in the activity of the breeding. Although at the beginning most of the members were Peulh groups, the composition of the groups is currently quite heterogeneous.
AREN is a national organization that is present in all regions of the country. AREN is recognized as the main organization of breeders of the country, but also as an important actor of the social peace and the development of the breeding in Niger.
At a closer level of its members, AREN plays a mediating role in the settlement and prevention of conflicts, such as settling land disputes, reclaiming pasture land improperly occupied by farmers, rehabilitating passage corridors etc. . . At the local level the members initiate numerous actions to defend the rights of breeders: fight against ransom, arbitrary arrests, illegal pounds, various legal proceedings against the abusers of power.
Among thegreat achievements is the consultation on the date of descent of the herds in the fields and dallols in the agricultural zones, andobtaining a revision of the basis of calculation of the damage caused by the animals and also the detention Abuse of animals in pounds. All this contributed significantly to the Association's brand image.
